hint_tier_notes: Tier 1: Restate question with simpler words + image. Tier 2: Demonstrate by revealing one option.
productive_failure_notes: Not appropriate. Y1 children need success experiences. Move to worked example immediately on error.
worked_example_style: Animated, narrated walkthrough with no text. Character models the thinking aloud.
agent_pedagogy_prompt: Always start with a fully narrated worked example showing the complete answer. Then immediately practise with the same type of problem. No challenge problems before instruction — Y1 children need success to build confidence. Keep each concept isolated; do not mix topics within a session. End every session positively.

hint_tier_notes: Tier 1: Restate question with visual cue. Tier 2: Narrow the options ('It is not A or B — which is left?').
productive_failure_notes: Not yet appropriate. Guided discovery (show the model, ask child to notice) is preferable to unguided challenge.
worked_example_style: Narrated with text displayed. Character models the thinking. Pause points for child to predict next step.
agent_pedagogy_prompt: Begin with a worked example — narrated and illustrated. Include pause-and-predict moments ('What do you think happens next?'). Then guided practice with scaffolding. Do not introduce new concepts without a worked example first. Space retrieval questions from previous sessions but do not mix question types within an activity.

hint_tier_notes: Tier 1: 'What do you already know about this?' Tier 2: 'Remember when we learned [related concept]?' Tier 3: 'The first step is to [specific procedure]...'
productive_failure_notes: Introduce challenge problem first; expect partial or incorrect attempts. Move to worked example after child has made one or more attempts. Effect size d=0.36–0.58 (Sinha & Kapur 2021).
worked_example_style: Text + diagram narrated. Step-by-step with child input at key points ('What would you do next?').
interleaving_notes: Mix this concept with 2–3 previously mastered concepts. Expect ~30–40% better transfer (Bjork 2011). Tell child: 'You are practising different types of problems — that is what makes you better.'
agent_pedagogy_prompt: Start with a challenge problem — do not explain first. Let the child attempt independently for 2–3 minutes. Collect their attempt. Then show the worked example. Follow with 3–4 retrieval practice questions that mix this concept with previously mastered material (interleaving). Contextualize difficulty: 'That one was harder — your brain was working to connect different ideas.'

hint_tier_notes: Tier 1: 'What do you know?' Tier 2: 'What is the first thing you need to find out?' Tier 3: 'If you [specific step], what do you get?'
productive_failure_notes: Full productive failure sequences appropriate. Unguided challenge → exploration → instruction → retrieval. Time on challenge: 3–5 minutes.
worked_example_style: Text-based with inline questions. Not fully narrated — child reads the example.
agent_pedagogy_prompt: Full productive failure sequence: challenge problem first (no instruction), then guided exploration with the interactive tool, then worked example, then independent retrieval practice with interleaving. Use Socratic questioning during exploration: 'What do you notice? What does that tell you?' Vary surface features of practice problems (different contexts, same underlying structure).

hint_tier_notes: Tier 1: 'What do you already know that might help?' Tier 2: 'Look at the problem — what type of problem is this?' Tier 3: 'What is the first step for this type of problem?' Tier 4: 'The answer involves [core idea]. Now work out why.'
productive_failure_notes: Standard learning sequence. Challenge should activate prior knowledge — design problems to surface prerequisite concepts. If child has no attempt after 5 minutes, provide Tier 1 hint.
worked_example_style: Text-based. Child completes partial worked examples (fading). Not fully narrated.
agent_pedagogy_prompt: Standard productive failure sequence. Include faded worked examples (child completes the last 1–2 steps). Generation effect: ask child to recall the rule/formula before showing it ('What do you remember about how fractions work?'). Interleave retrieval practice heavily. Vary surface features substantially to support transfer. Session can sustain 6–8 distinct question types.

hint_tier_notes: Tier 1: Meta-question 'What type of problem is this?' Tier 2: 'What approach would you try?' Tier 3: Domain-specific procedural prompt. Tier 4: 'The answer is [X] — now justify why this is correct.'
productive_failure_notes: Standard. Extend challenge phase to 5–7 minutes. Design challenges that admit multiple solution approaches — document child's approach for feedback.
worked_example_style: Student-completed faded examples. Text-based. Example solutions shown for comparison after independent attempt.
metacognitive_notes: Post-task reflection: 'What made that hard?' 'What would you do differently?' 'What did you learn?'
agent_pedagogy_prompt: Full desirable difficulties suite. Challenge problem first with 5–7 minutes autonomous time. Multiple solution paths are welcome — document approach. Faded worked examples as standard. End session with metacognitive reflection questions. Testing effect: use retrieval-only practice (no re-study) for previously mastered content. Space at 7/14/21 day intervals.

hint_tier_notes: Similar to Y6. Tier 4 may reveal solution for especially novel content.
productive_failure_notes: Standard. Secondary challenge problems can span multiple sessions.
worked_example_style: Text-based. Reference solutions available after independent attempt.
agent_pedagogy_prompt: Secondary level productive failure. Challenge problems can be open-ended and multi-day. Worked examples as reference, not instruction. Metacognitive reflection standard after each session. Retrieval-only practice for mastered content. Interleave across KS3 topic strands.

hint_tier_notes: Tier 1: Conceptual frame question. Tier 2: Methodological prompt. Tier 3: Worked example reference.
productive_failure_notes: Standard secondary PF. Extended exploration phase appropriate.
worked_example_style: Reference examples available on demand. Not shown by default.
agent_pedagogy_prompt: Minimal scaffolding. Worked examples on-demand only. Extended challenge phase. Metacognitive reflection built into session end. Retrieval practice from across KS3 topics. Longer spacing intervals (5–28 days) for robust long-term retention.

hint_tier_notes: Tier 1: 'What approach might you take?' Tier 2: Subject-specific method cue. Tier 3: Model answer for comparison.
productive_failure_notes: Full secondary/GCSE-prep PF. Multi-part problems appropriate. Document reasoning chains.
worked_example_style: Mark scheme and model answer available after independent attempt.
agent_pedagogy_prompt: GCSE preparation pedagogy. Multi-part exam-style questions as standard. Mark scheme and model answer revealed after independent attempt. Self-assessment against mark scheme encouraged. Metacognitive debrief: 'How did your answer compare? What would earn more marks?' Interleave across GCSE topic areas. Long-gap spacing for retrieval practice.

hint_tier_notes: Tier 1: 'What does the question require?' Tier 2: Subject-specific method or framework cue. Tier 3: Model answer for comparison after attempt.
productive_failure_notes: Full GCSE-level productive failure. Multi-part exam questions as challenge problems. Extended exploration phase (10+ minutes) appropriate for complex problems.
worked_example_style: Mark scheme and examiner report excerpts available after independent attempt. Model answers for comparison, not instruction.
agent_pedagogy_prompt: GCSE Year 1 pedagogy. Full exam-style questions with mark allocations. Students attempt independently before seeing mark scheme. Self-assessment and mark scheme comparison central. Retrieval practice should span the full specification studied so far. Interleave across topic areas within each subject. Longer spacing intervals (7–42 days) for durable retention. Metacognitive reflection: 'What marks would you award your answer? Why?'

hint_tier_notes: Tier 1: 'Re-read the question — what command word is used?' Tier 2: Model answer for comparison after timed attempt.
productive_failure_notes: Examination-level productive failure. Timed conditions appropriate. Multi-mark questions spanning multiple assessment objectives.
worked_example_style: Examiner reports and grade boundary analysis available after timed attempt. Focus on what distinguishes grade boundaries.
prerequisite_gating_notes: At Y11, revision sessions should revisit weak areas regardless of mastery status — exam preparation requires revisiting all content.
agent_pedagogy_prompt: GCSE examination year pedagogy. Timed exam-style questions under realistic conditions. Self-assessment against mark schemes is the primary feedback mechanism. Retrieval practice spans the entire GCSE specification. Interleave heavily across all topic areas. Focus on grade-boundary-crossing improvements: 'What specific addition would move this from a 6 to a 7?' Metacognitive reflection on exam technique, time management, and mark allocation strategy.
